awd_titl_txt: Improved Methods for Including Vibronic and Environmental Effects in Simulations of Optical Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Christine Isborn of the University of California Merced is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry to develop and apply improved methods for simulating optical spectroscopy.  Her research focuses on how the environment (e.g. solvent, surface, protein) surrounding a chromophore (light absorber) affects the electronic excited states. New simulation techniques will be developed that better represent atomistic and experimental details.
The new methods for simulating optical spectroscopy in complex environments can be used to guide the design of new molecules and materials that have desired optical properties. Improved tools for simulating optical spectroscopy will improve understanding of electronic excitation processes in complex environments, with the potential for this increased understanding to drive new technologies in the fields of photovoltaics, electro-optics, or photo-catalysis.  Professor Isborn also engages in broader impact activities at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate student levels. To serve a primarily first-generation student population, undergraduate students create short videos in both English and the student’s native language in which they discuss their experiences. A week-long graduate student level summer school focused on the fundamentals and applications of computer theory helps to train the next generation of chemists for the workforce of the future. 

Optical spectroscopy, including optical absorption, fluorescence, and time-resolved ultrafast electronic spectroscopy, is the most commonly used technique for probing the electronic behavior of many chemical systems and molecular reactions. These methods are sensitive to environmental effects, however, traditional approaches for modeling optical spectra of molecules in complex environments often fail to reproduce spectral shapes due to either lacking vibronic effects and/or missing specific interactions between the molecule and its environment. Professor Isborn and her group are developing a family of approaches for simulating optical absorption, fluorescence, and ultrafast spectra that account for both vibronic transitions and specific solute-solvent-environment interactions by computing ground and excited vibrational modes in the presence of the atomistic environment. They are examining how the environment affects spectral shapes and electronic relaxation for a variety of chromophores within complex environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we have developed theoretical methods for including vibronic and specific environmental effects in optical spectroscopy simulations.  Our overarching goal with this project has been to develop approaches for improved simulations of linear and nonlinear optical spectroscopy and to bring insight into the factors governing condensed phase chromophore lineshapes. 

We have developed and validated a family of approaches for simulating optical spectra that account for both vibronic transitions and specific solute-solvent-environment interactions. For this family of approaches, we combined an ensemble of solute-solvent environment configurations with Franck-Condon (FC) lineshapes and with to developed three hybrid ensemble-FC approaches that systematically include more rigor, along with accompanying increase in computational cost, to include environment and configuration specific FC shape functions.

Some key results:

  • Two of the three E-FC methods give remarkably good agreement across a range of systems.
  • Sampling of chromophore-solvent snapshots during an ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) QM/MM trajectory suggests from the Stokes shift and potential energy surface (PES) analysis that MM solvent is too close to the QM chromophore, leading to overly strong solute-solvent interactions and an overly large Stokes shift.
  • Vibronic Franck-Condon spectra computed in explicit solvent are quite sensitive to the density functional method, much more so than the implicit solvent spectra. 

We have examined how the solvent/environment affects spectral shapes within both our new family of methods and within simulated two-dimensional electronic spectra (2D-ES), determining how environmental effects control both spectral shape and energy relaxation timescales. Our methods allow decomposition into how environment affects inhomogeneous broadening and how environment affects vibronic spectra.  A key physical insight we have made as part of this project is that the strong peripheral H-bonds do not contribute to inhomogeneous broadening in either linear or nonlinear spectra, but the solvent axial to the chromophore, which may engage in H-bonding, dominates the inhomogeneous broadening.  Additionally, we have found that MM solvent surrounding a QM chromophore restricts the vibrational fluctuations and motion of the chromophore, leading to an overly narrow vibronic spectrum.  Use of QM solvent during the optimization, and presumably also in the AIMD trajectory, leads to broader vibronic spectra.

We have also been developing 2DES analysis for direct comparison with nonlinear spectroscopy experiments. We have been able to separate vibronic and specific solvent contributions through inclusion of certain solvent molecules in our energy gap correlation functions.

Educational broader impact activities for this project include (i) building a community of TDDFT developers and users, (ii) undergraduate student outreach including exposing a diverse, primarily first generation group of students to research early on in their undergraduate trajectory through the creation of short videos of current and previous UC Merced students explaining their research pathway.

For the first of our educational outreach activities, the PI has co-organized the 2023 TDDFT and Excited States Summer School at Rutgers University (https://sites.rutgers.edu/tddft/ ) and has provided significant participant support as funded by this award.  Over 50 students were able to attend the 5 days of the summer school, followed by the 4 days of the workshop.  The school was intended for early career researchers who wanted to gain understanding of how to simulate time-dependent quantum dynamics and charge transfer phenomena with DFT and TDDFT. Morning theory lectures and afternoon hands-on lectures covered fundamentals of DFT and TDDFT.  The workshop showcased cutting-edge multidisciplinary research in DFT and TDDFT.  The specific lectures given by the PI included Charge Transfer in TDDFT and Excited States in Solution.

As part of this project, the PI has also been organizing the creation and posting of content and interviews of current and former students.  We have found that we can reach more students through social media than through posting our videos in classrooms. For student interviews, student video assistants created content for UC Merced's new Instagram account, connecting a predominantly first-generation and diverse student population with resources (Chem Center study hours, Career Center activities, research opportunities, basic needs options), giving them examples of success along the STEM career path of people that come from a similar background (peers, near-peers, grad students, and former students now in industry), and helping to build a strong community of learners.
